bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Bruce Mayne, February 2, 1922

div1.p: Carter critiques Mayne's manuscript on the Anopheles mosquito.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Bruce Mayne, February 2, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
N. M. C.
Mayne
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
Feb. 2, 1922.
Dear Mayne:
div1.p:
I am returning your MSS. with criticisms. I am marking the Mar-
gins: (1): (2) etc. and in this paper saying what I think is true of
these places.

(1) This paragraph is most true. I have always preached this
and have said that I believed Koch's long administration of quinine
was not only to sterilize his carriers, but to keep them free from
infection--i. e. uninfectable--until the infected Anopheles in flight
died. Of course, this was on the supposition that active Anopheles
might carry infection as long as they lived.

(2) True. I think I might be inclined to insert the words “un-
der different conditions” after “viability.”

(3) This is all right and timely. Would not the logical con-
nection be better preserved by removing the 2nd. sentence of this
par., so as to be the 4th. as indicated. Just a change in form.
Don't you mean too: “it is known to what definite periods mosquitoes
harbor malaria parasites.”

(4) Am glad that you brought this out again. Anopheles may
exist and be of little sanitary importance. on account of small number

(5) This temperature was doubtless chosen to produce the maximum
longevity of (intermittently?) active Anopheles. It is not far from
the winter temperature of Memphis or--say--Natchez. Were they not
“sprawled” part of the time?

It seems to me rather a study of longevity in hibernation (in-
(in-
2
termittent hibernation as we have it in the South) than under natural
conditions of activity--which is what (1) stated it was desireable to
determine.
(6) Temperatures might be given, I presume, higher than in (5).

(7) Should not you change your word “subsist” as she “sustains
life on a vegetable diet?” Does she require blood for oviposition
of fertile eggs?

(8) What number (of each species) were found infected? At what in-
terval after the blood-meal were the degenerated sporozoits found?

it is hard to say if parasites would develope at this temperature or
no--certainly it was about the lower limit for it. The mean of extremes
is 61%--what the mean was, one does not know.

(9) “Up to 74 days” seems indefinite. If applied, say, from the
15th. day on, I would conclude that my Anppheles never became infective--
i. E. never had efficient sporozoits in their salivary glands--or else the
men bitten were unusually insusceptible.

(10) I understand that the insects containing these P. fals. also
failed to infect and that these sporozoits were “sluggishly motile” also.
Am I right?

(11) I understand, this was a mosquito of Par. 8: kept, except the
first 6 days, at low temperature? (12) and (13): Tend to show that failure
to infect man is insufficient evidence of absence of living sporozoits in
the salivary glands: Were these “lively sporozoits” actively motile or no?

It seems to me, however, that for your determinations of (1) length
of Anopheles life in nature: (2) length of time she remains infected for
the purpose of par. (1) of this article, that the observations must be
made under more nearly normal conditions of temperature etc. than those
you have detailed. It seems to me you have worked almost under the con-
ditions of hibernation.

Obviously, since what we really wish to determine (for the purposes
purposes
3
of Par. (1) is the duration of the infectivity of A. to man, the ideal
way would be to depend on human experiments. This, I think, is not jus-
tifiable, and, in spite of the findings of (12) and (13) of your paper,
I judge that we will have to judge her infective when we find living
(active) sporozoits in her salivary glands.

In any case, it seems to me necessary to keep your mosquitoes at a
temperature as near as possible the natural one at the time,
since you wish to apply your findings to the purposes of (1) in your
paper.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. Address
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C;
